column4: I take it you burned a dvd and it's not working in said dvd player? Was it a 'data' dvd? (i.e. had mp4's on it that you wanted to play through your dvd player?)
correct
I suppose it is concievable. Does the dvd read properly in other devices?
It reads properly in the same PC and a windows PC
Ok, have you checked online to see if your dvd player requires data disks in a specific format and/or hierarchy?

They won't be specific. They claim to support every disc type, and the MP4 files are generated by an ffmpeg/x264 I've compiled and scripted myself. High profile, "a few b-frames". I know the mp4 files are good.
Ok. So when you burned it did you tell it to close the disk?
That's the thing. I can't see how to see it to do so
I don't recall setting any such option either way, but this Ubuntu install has been going since '09
Do you remember seeing an option that said "leave open" with a checkbox?
Oh jeez, now you're getting technical.
I'm a PHP programmer, I can't deal with this level of detail
hehe
Right up to the final burn dialog, there are no "close" or "not close" related options. I'm somewhat familiar with the standards and filesystems, multi-session etc options. I see none.
So I wonder if Brasero by default uses different settings, it's iso9660+joliet from memory, as standard?
Sorry, perils of computering outside. Bird just crapped on my laptop...
LOL that's pretty epic.
Can you suggest a DVD creator that has advanced options? I only require data DVDs and RW blanking.
lol
I have heard good things of k3b. Brasero has worked fine for me.
I'll try it too, thanks and good night. Also, good luck with the laptop.
But I've never needed many of the more advanced options.
Oh it's cleaned up now.
Perhaps, but I'll remember you for it ;)
